330 ml bottle ¬ì2013Vintage¬î bought at HK Brewcraft in Tsim Sha Tsui.
Looks: Clear deep reddish brown colour with a layer of dirt-like yeast sediments; Less than one-quarter finger head with residual soapy light beige foam which fades in 20 seconds; Fair sticky lacing with near zero carbonation.

Aroma: Very fragrant and sweet dark malt, with strong dessert wine, red wine, Bourbon, immense caramel, sticky toffee, strong alcohol, strong plums, strong raisins, sugar, spices, barrels, bread, yeast and light grass. Lovely sweetness!

Taste: Strong sweet dark malt, with strong green grapes, moderate Port wine, red wine, Bourbon, strong alcohol, very strong plums, raisins, strong caramel, toffee, floral, strong molasses, strong spices, fair barrels, light biscuits, lemon, medium bitter hops and grass.

Body: Close to full body. Quite thick and slightly oily palate.

Mouth Feel: Very good dark maltyness - well-attenuated - in a very slick background. Full mouthful of green grapes followed closely by intense dark fruits. Bourbon took a back seat as red wine and port wine factors are much stronger and nicer. Good caramel with surprisingly moderate medioum sweetness with further sips. Spicy and lemony to round. Excellent!

Booze: the 11% abv is upfront and strong, must be treated with respect but is mostly nice comfy red wine smoothness instead of harsh liquor at this level. Sweetness and liquorices are moderate due to high attenuation. Blended well with the Bourbon barrels. Great!

Hoppiness: Spices and light grass in nose. Floral, strong spices, lemon and grass in taste; Bitterness is fairly strong for an abrupt, medium astringent sweet-bitter malty finish.

After Taste: Quite dry. Winey spicy and fairly bitter to mouth.

Comments: This is so different from other rich dark Struise Ales I¬íve had - a strong dark ale base which is lean and mean with hearty dark fruits and caramel characters. The Bourbon barrels landed some unexpected fruity vineyards and red wineyness. Strong comfy booze with just right sweetness. Spicy hops is never far behind. A unorthodox Quad which is nice in its own way. Highly recommended!

Aroma:

Medium aroma of malts, caramel, wood, whiskey, dried fruit, liquorice, chocolate and roasted malts.

Appearance:

Turbid/opaque red/dark brown beer with heavy yeast and with no/a slight beige head.

Taste/Palate:

Starts heavy sweet with malts, caramel, wood, whiskey, dried fruit, liquorice and chocolate; ends slightly bitter and dry with roasted malts.

Overall:

This beer is intense, complex and balanced. Thanks to that long aging on that bourbon barrel and the rather heavy amount of roasted malts, this almost does not feel like a Belgian beer and even less like a Quad. No matter what style it gets labeled as, this beer is great beyond belief. The aroma could have been stronger and the head could be bigger, though that last one could be forgiven thanks to that aging.

Sampled at Het Oude Schooltje; July 2010,br>
The beer pours with an amber tinged, dark tan colored head that sits on top of a dark, burnt amber hued beer.  When held up to the light the beer shows a brilliantly clear, red / ruby / brown hue.  This has a nice candi-sugar influenced nose to it, with notes of dark fruit (prune and raisin being definitely noticeable) and there is an earthy spice character to it as well as some sweet spice (like Christmas) aromas here.  I can pick out notes of clove, ginger, and a hint of pepper, but there is quite a bit going on here.

The beer tastes quite sweet as it hits the palate, but much of this comes from the base fruitiness and the sweet accentuating spiciness that is found in this beer.  The finish is dry with a spicy note as well as a touch of astringency.  The fruit flavors found here remind me of bright plums, tart-sweet raisins and even some fig notes add to the complexity.  Flavors of rum, or perhaps more properly characterized as brandy flavors are brought out by the sweetness, the fruit character and the alcohol.  This is really quite nicely balanced between the fruit character, the alcohol, the earthy spiciness and the candi sugar flavors.  This has the proper character needed of being light and quaffable for its strength; it is still most definitely a sipping beer, but it is not overly heavy or cloying.  The sipping also allows one to fully experience the complexity and myriad of balanced flavors.

Tastes rich, with yeasty spicy dank malts (Jesus, that¬ís the 2nd time I¬íve used the word dank in a description after perhaps never using it before), with some fruity cherry notes, estery old aley esters, and a very complex and well hidden alcoholic palate.  Very smooth, and evolves to a more fruity specimen late, and always stays complex and at the top of the heap.  Well done, guys.
Amber colour, rather syrupy nose with malts and caramel. Taste is much the same, caramel and syrup, not a stand-out but okay. Firmly in the middle of the pack as far as this beer style goes.

Reddish brown colour with mediumsized beigeish head. Aroma is caramel, spices, some toffee as well as mild notes of alcohol. Flavour is caramel malts, toffee, spices, some mild alcohol as well as some chocolaty notes as well. Probably needs a bit of time still, but can get even bigger at some point.

Aroma is fruity, plum, rasin, honey, apple and som viniousity. Pours dark chestnut with red/orange edges and an off white creamy head. Flavour is rasin, plum, apple, roaste, bread and again some viniousity. Nice soft mouthfeel with a long roasted aftertaste.

Bottle, bought @ the Struise Webshop.
[my 6,500th rating]
A lovely dark red chestnut with a medium, creamy, off-white head. Aroma is sweet. Lots of plums, hazelnuts, estery yeast, overripe red apples, some slight banana, caramel and a slight hint of milky chocolate. Medium carbonation, lovely creamy mouthfeel with some good dryness. Bottle at Chris O¬ís ¬íRaise the Roof" tasting. Brown pour with a beige head. Raisins and figs in the nose. Figs, dates, raisins and dried fruit flavours. Smooth Christmas feel. Sweet, warm finish.

2010 bottle from Kaashoeve Veurne. Dark brown, with off-white head (not lasting too long). Aroma is very sweet at first, with sweetbread, chocolatecake, toffee, and later with some herbs and fruit (raisin, apple). Taste is sweet, sugary, and there is something funky that¬ís hard to describe. Alcohol is well detectable at first, but seems to mellow a bit later. Finishes with some funky spiciness. Nice, but not great.

Had this on tap at pre-zbf, but sample appeared to be too young. 33cl bottle. Small off-white head over a brow-reddish beer. Aroma is dark fruits, banana. Taste is sweet, again dark fruit, raisins,  banana and spices. In the end a pleasant and boozy taste kicks in. Mouthfeel is creamy and rich. Alot better then the sample I had on tap.

Bottle thanks to someone at Sourfest. Pours with a brown body and a tan head. Aroma is brown sugar, raisins, brandy and alcohol. Taste is alcohol, dates and persimmons. Alcoholic and big mouthfeel. Nice.

Vintage 2010 bottle at Kulminator. Dark brown, almost black with a tan little head. Intense sweet licorice aroma. Aniseed, caramel sweetness. A bit cloying. Nice and rich, but too much on the sweet side, I think.

4th March 2010. Pre ZBF. Cloudy brown beer. No head. Pretty low carbonation. Rich malty beer with a sweet bubblegum undertone. Finishes dry and with some good fruit notes coming through. Very drinkable.

Bottle vintage 2010 shared with Chris at Ebenezer¬ís. Big thanks for this one. Pours out a dark mahogany topped with a tan head. Aroma was great with lots of fruit, caramel, and spice. Taste was much of the same sweetness, some wood, nutty, and plenty pit fruit.

Bottle.

Heavy beer with great similarites with the Pannepot brews, which I find better.

Sweet, spicy, licorice and dark fruits.

Bottle. Pours a clear and dark mahogany beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is fruit, yeast and gum. The flavor follows the nose with some alcoholwarmth. The palate is sweet with alcohol. Overall a good beer.
11oz bottle.  Cloudy reddish amber with a small bubbly off white head.  Nice nutty aroma with caramel, toffee and a faint herbal hop presence.  Glad I got to try this.
Vintage 2010. Pours brown with a beige head. Aroma is caramel, heavy fruit, raisin, plum, chewing gum and yeast. Flavour is malt, alcohol, fruit, chewing gum, raisin and yeast.

Bottle. Pours black with a latte coloured head. The aroma has got notes of milk chocolate, wine and some spices. Lots of dried fruit, milk chocolate and orange in the taste. Finishes vinous. This beer succeeds to be sweet without being pushy. Big bodied. I would have like a little more complexity, but I think this one will be great after a couple of years in the cellar.

bottle courtesy of Urbain @ Struise.
pours deep mahogany with light off-white head. Finally a quad on the other side of Vleteren.
aroma of  light bourbon, plenty of dark fruits and candi sugar.
flavors, quad palate is outstanding, the addition of the bourbon really adds a nice dimension to the beer especially at this abv style, yet not overtaking the whole profile. Nicely sweet of candi sugar meshing nicely with the dark fruits along with some caramelized notes.
Aging a few bottles, this is outstanding and well executed.
UPDATED: SEP 3, 2014 33cl, as Sint Amatus 12, Vintage 2013, new exclusive brew Anno 2010, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex brew, balanced, cloudy, good head, very good brew, yet expensive!

Vintage 2010. Bottle @ Johnny¬ís off license, Rome. Pours dark brown with a small creamy head and lacings. Nose is yeast, fruit and bubblegum. Sweet and quite complex. Full bodied. Ripe fruity flavor with caramel, chewing gum and a whiff of alcohol.  Fine

head: normal, tan

Pours a dark brown color with a nice tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts, dark fruits, plums and raisins, honey, spices and a hint of liquor.  Flavors of roasted malts, hops, caramels, some dark plums and raisins, spices and liquorice, and some brown sugars.  Good carbonation, light sweet and bitter, smooth and a bit creamy. Some hints of oak wood in the end.  Very complex and nice balance of great flavors.   The is really nice, so enjoyable to drink and packed with great flavors. Love it, nice one Urbain!

Vintage 2010. #25. Pours a dark reddish-brown with a small head that fades real quickly. The aroma is sweet, brown sugar, fruity, raisins, bready, intensely sweet. Like some sweet bread with fruit, and raisins. The taste is alcohol at first, sweet, more raisins, bready, and kind of hot at its young age. The mouthfeel has some softness to it.

Pours dark with a good head. The aroma is fruity, fresh, with caramel, herbs. the palate if nice, but a bit on the light side, just like a westvleteren 12. the flavor follows the aroma adding some malt, coffee, cane sugar. A very good beer on the trapist style.

Beautiful aroma of sweet dry fruits  and a hint of alcohol.  Deep amber-brown in color with a small tan head.  Extremely smooth drinking, with outstanding balance.  Nice moderate sweetness with a great subtle hop balance.  Not particularly spicey, just smooth off the barrel and good!

Dark brown pour, small beige head- very comparable to Westy¬ís 8. Aroma holds lots of doughy yeast, spice, raisin, molasses, caramel, and plum-- really nice dark fruit character. Flavor is comparable; angel food cake, yeast, caramel, Belgian spice, and caramel; again, very comparable to the 8. Perhaps more balanced and more sugary than 8, but less aggressive in the yeast character. Another damn good de Struise brew.

dark brown pour, light brown head, nice lacing, 
aroma is dark fruit, yeast and spice, nicely balanced.  
flavor is light yeastiness, dough, dark sugar, a bit of burnt sugar, angel food cake, some light cinnamon.  nicely balanced.  Nice job Urbain.

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2010 Thanks for the free bottle Peter. The pour is very dark brown- almost black. Tons of dark fruit in the nose- raisin, plum, and fig with some light grape notes and yeasty dough character. A light spice character comes in as she warms. A pleasant yeast character in the form of angelfood cake dough gives way to dark fruit in the form of raisin and plum. Molasses and dark sugar give way to some toffee and caramel notes. The palate is thick and creamy with a sugary finish.

2010 bottle pour to Trappist glass.  Cloudy dark brownish-red with minimal tan head that fades quickly to a ring.  Aroma sweet fruits.  Taste red fruits, slight dates/raisins, sweet malts, yeasts.  Palate rich and smooth.  Finish long with fruits, just a hint of bitterness.  Very nice balance.

Nice quadrupel with not quite the richness of the top Trappists but still really good.  Maybe will improve with some aging.

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2010 Bottle at home. Was really interested to taste this beer. Pours out very dark, close to black. Medium off-white, maybe even beide head, that holds ok. Sweet smell of red fruits, caramel, someting pleasant inside. Oily body, really nice sticky taste. Sweet caramel and fruits, nicely spiced. Could use just some more carbonation, a little to less for me, but doable. And maybe just a bit less sweetness. Good lightly bitter aftertaste with red fruits inside. I like it for sure.

Edit: Another bottle, tastes even better it seems.
Tap @ pre-ZBF 2010. Dark color, creamy head. Slight sweet, some hop, malt. Fruity. Good tribute to westy 12 (might be even better?)

Draught at pre-ZBF, courtesy of Urbain - thank you sir!  Deep maroon color, thick beige Guinness-like head.  Aroma of chocolate chip, prunes, pears.  Taste is rich and smooth, dark fruits plus caramel, slight bit of whisky and some burnt espresso toward the finish.  Very nice.
@ Pre ZBF. The aroma has fresh fruitiness, juniper. Hazy, brown coloured beer with an off-white, medium head. The taste is malty, smooth, has juniper and fresh fruits. Medium bodied.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2010 Draught @ pre-ZBF Festival 2010, Kasteel der Lakebosschen, Lakebosschendreef 4, Ruddervoorde, Belgium.Clear medium brown color with a average, frothy - creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, light beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, caramel, sweet malt, moderate yeasty, sweet licorice, riped and dried fruit. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20100304]

Draught at Struise School. Mahogany with creamy beige head. Nose and flavour of dark fruits, chocolate, caramel, oak and very yeastie. Smooth and bitter that leads to a rich malty finish. Delicious and yet delicate in all aspects. Very nice.

On tap at Pre ZBF 2010.  Quite a fruity choccy quad.  A little young maybe as esters still quite present.  Pretty good quad though, smooth in mouth.  Reminded me of a Rocheforst in the style.  Will be great in 6-12 months when I hope to re-rate it.
Had this one at the Pre-ZBF 2010. Brown colored brew. Hoppy, fruity aroma. Flavor is fruity, sweet, malty, hay.

A Mes rate. Draught at Pre ZBF and then again at Struise School a few days afterwards.Murky brown colour with a thin tan head, in all honesty, it¬ís not the most attractive looking Struise beer. Once it hits the other senses however it all comes much more together. Amazing oaky chocolate and preserve fruit. Big alcohol but in a really enjoyable way. Stunningly smooth though. The fruit and caramel intermingle so well, as do the spice and bitterness. Considerably better at the school once it had time to settle down a little. It just seemed a little too early at the festival. The scores are a combination of the two times I¬íve tried it but I would thoroughly expect them to jump up a little once I¬íve had a chance to try the bottled version.

Draft @ pre-ZBF March 5, 2010. Pours a deep, muddy brown. Initially topped with a huge beige head that settles to a 5mm cover. Sweet aroma, with notes of caramel malt, dark fruit, pear. and citrus. Flavor is fairly sweet, begins with some bicuity malt, complimented by toffee, dark fruit and some citric hops. Medium to full bodied. Not as exciting as the other beers Struise debuted at pre-ZBF, but still pretty solid. Very drinkable.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2010 Pilot batch on tap at the schoolhouse with Urbeer and Travlr. Poured a cloudy, muddy brown with a very lively tan head. Aroma of Bosc pears, spices, cinnamon oatmeal, rum raisin. Taste is raw oatmeal, maple candies, almost a doppelbock sweetness that is put in check by balancing hops and spices. I would very much like to try to finalized version. Excellent, silky palate. 11%+ is totally hidden. 3/15/2010 8/4/8/4/14=3.8 330mL courtesy of Travlr. Pours a deep, hazy brune with a massive tan head that leaves sticky, layered lacing. Aroma has gained a touch of Flemish sour funk, steak, red wine reduction, meat, caramel, wood. Taste is malt-forward, some dry cocoa, touch of lemon tartness. None of the Woodford Reserve bourbon comes through unfortunately. 12/19/2010 8/4/7/4/14=3.7

Had this at Pre ZBF 5th March 2010   Pours brown  though difficult to be exact on this because of the poor light in the area of the castle where we are currently, there is a light beige head. This is sweet, quite fruity, and sits quite heavy in the mouth at first, a touch of yeast and some tropical fruits start to show, as does the alcohol, I wonder whether this is a little young and needs more time to develop and soften those hard edges out a little.  A6 A3 F7 P3 Ov13   3.2

From tap, Hazy looking orange-brown beer with creamy beige-yellow foam on top. Strange, but the foam was topping this beer in three different looking layers. Aroma is rich, sweet, malty and has hints of raisins and touches of a french dessert called babba au rum. The taste is almost silky, it has hints of caramel, milk chocolate, some fruits and lots of rich malts. it ends with a soft bitterness of hops and a nice long caramel like aftertaste.

On Tap @ 3de Pre-ZBF. A hazy dark red/brown colored beer, with tick foamy beige head. The aroma of several fruits like cherry, pear and appel and some dark malts. The taste of some bitter hops with fruits like citrus and cheries. A little sweet. The aftertaste is bitter and dry with some sweet.

Unclear deep amber with a medium beige head. Sweet aroma with overripe fruits, toasted malt, caramel and biscuits. Flavour was sweet with toasted malt, caramel, ripe fruits and hoppy notes. Alcohol nicely hidden but somewhat one dimensional.

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2013 (bottle) pours a dark murky ruby-brown colour with a creamy beige head. aroma of bubble gum, brown sugar, yeast, figs, dates, candy sugar, caramel and a hint of bread dough. flavour is mostly roasted malts and bread crusts, slightly buttery, with a hint of white grapes, alcohol and a light-bitter herbal-hoppy finish. heavy-bodied with average carbonation.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2010 Draught at Pre-ZBF 2010. Cloudy amber - light brown head. Yeasty, wheaty, high yeasty, caramel, fruity, duasty, amber malts, sweetness,Apples. Pears, candy, ripe fruits, spicy, tobacco. Boring.

Draught. Dark amber coloured. Light brown small head. Ripe fruits, spice and light caramelly sweetness in the aroma. Flavour of sweetness, ripe fruits, spice and caramel. Medium to full bodied. Sweet and fruity end with a distinct touch of alcohol.

Draught at PreZBF 2010.
Muddy red brown coloured with a medium sized beige head.
Sweet aroma of caramel, fruits and hops.
Sweet and fruity flavour of caramel, dried fruits, yeast and tobacco.
Dry fruity and yeasty finish.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2010 Draft @ Pre-ZBF. Deep brown pour, slight tanned head.
Aroma of faint liquorice and some hops.
Deep bitter flavour, evolving to a sweet yeasty sugar flavour.
On draft at 3rd pre-ZBF. Pours a hazy orange brown color with an off-white orange head that laces. Aroma of licorice, mint and hops. Flavor is slightly sweet, of oak and a bit of sugar.

From tap at pre-ZBF. Pours hazy dark amber to dark brown with a thick, creamy and tan head. Aroma is roasted and mild fruity. Fruity, yeasty, dark breadish to toffee caramelish. Light alcohol presence. Phenolic and dry malty flavoured into the finish. Lasting smooth malty impression.

Draught  Medium white rim over fully opaque dark red-brown beer. Quite perfumed nose, dark fruit, dark malts. Sweet-alcoholic flavour; sweet dark fruit, bananaester, some discreet but present fusels. Good oily, slick MF, not viscous nor pappy. Nice beer, if too young @ tasting - taster and brewer agree - which makes it hard to tell if the intended is reached. To be retried.
